newsitem.title: USA: Congress sends Clinton budget bill for signature.
newsitem.headline: Congress sends Clinton budget bill for signature.

text.p: The Senate passed a budget accord on Monday and sent it to President Clinton, who pledged to sign the spending bill before midnight to avoid a partial shutdown of the government.

The bill for fiscal 1997 starting at midnight rolled ogether six spending bills that would ordinarily be considered separately. It also incorporated a once-contentious immigration bill and a measure to strengthen the thrift insurance fund.
The bill passed the Senate on a 84-15 vote, after clearing the House on Saturday in a 370-37 vote.

The compromise bill, providing $356 billion for domestic programs and $244 billion for the military, granted the president extra money he requested. Clinton successfully sought an additional $6.5 billion for domestic spending, with $4 billion of that going to education.
For months Republicans resisted giving him the extra money. But in the end many became anxious to complete work so they could go home to campaign for re-election Nov. 5.

The bill covered military spending, national parks, education, jobs programs, environmental protection and law enforcement, the White House, foreign aid, health research, and many other activities. It also provided money for anti-terrorism measures and sold radio spectrum.
